Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High Performance Digital 400 MHz NMR Spectrometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program, Professor David Saiki from California State University-Bakersfield and colleagues Andreas Gebauer, Carl Kloock, Danielle Solano and Karlo Lopez will acquire a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research training and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) self-diffusion measurements of solution phase hexameric insulin; (b) synthesis of macrocyclic systems; (c) synthesis of bioactive cyclic peptide natural products and their derivatives; (d) synthesis, screning and development of small molecule inhibitors of lysyl oxidase; and (c) identification of compounds responsible for fluorescence in terrestrial arthropods.

Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) spectroscopy is one of the most powerful tools available to chemists for the elucidation of the structure of molecules. It is used to identify unknown substances, to characterize specific arrangements of atoms within molecules, and to study the dynamics of interactions between molecules in solution. Access to state-of-the-art NMR spectrometers is essential to chemists who are carrying out frontier research. The results from these NMR studies will have an impact in synthetic organic/inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research at the California State University-Bakersfield and neighboring institutions such as such as Tuft and Bakersfield College.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project funded the acquisition of a 400 MHz NMR spectrometer.  This instrument has enabled, and will continue to enable, research and training opportunities in the chemical sciences at California State University Bakersfield.  This acquisition has helped to sustain faculty research and enabled the department to expand the number of courses and laboratories.  Greater numbers of chemistry majors have been recruited and the department has been able to graduate approximately 30% more majors in the past few years.  Due in part to this growth, two additional chemistry faculty have been able to be recruited and will use this instrument to provide further research and training opportunities to our students.  Undergraduate researches have been able to attend local and national conferences to present their work which utilized the NMR spectrometer. Approximately 150 students have been trained on this instrument during the organic course sequence within the past year.   Curriculum that incorporates this instrumentation within the chemistry program has been developed as CSUB transitions to from the quarter to semester system.  Also within the grant period, high school students worked on a research project during the summer.  CSUB, a Hispanic serving institution that serves many first generation students, is the only institution within a 100 mile radius that provides a 4-year chemistry degree.  This project has had significant impact on the capacity and quality of the chemistry program at CSUB and has furthered the mission and goals of the department and university.
